Study: Modelling the potential impact of social distancing on the COVID-19 epidemic in South Africa
Factors: social distancing i.e. keeping space between yourself and other people outside your home
Excerpt: Reducing the level of social distancing from 55% to 53% (ρ = 0.47) would increase the number of cumulative cases by about 23% at the end of lock-down on 30 April 2020; Increasing the level of social distancing from 55% to 57% (ρ = 0.43), 59% (ρ = 0.41) and 61% (ρ = 0.39) would avert the cumulative cases by about 18%, 32% and 53% respectively at the end of lockdown on 30 April 2020
Measure of Evidence: Countries: South Africa; Timeline: March 5th (day one) with lockdown initiated on day 21 and ending on 30 April 2020

Study: Mathematical modeling of COVID-19 containment strategies with considerations for limited medical resources
Factors: social distancing, where members of the population systematically reduce their interactions with other to limit the transmission rate of the virus
Excerpt: the Distancing-SEIRD model predicted the total number on deaths over a six month period with no social distancing to be as high as 130,000 people;  the most strict case of social distancing, with 80% adherence, led to a drastic reduction in the death toll - to under 1000 total deaths over the first six months
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Canada cities: Ontario; Timeline: Jan 25th, 2020 with social distancing beginning on March 17th

Study: Estimating the impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions on documented infections with COVID-19: A cross-country analysis
Factors: prohibition of small gatherings in public or private places
Excerpt: gathering bans (34 %; 95% CI 21-45 %) reduction in the number of new cases
Measure of Evidence: Countries: United States, Canada, Australia, the EU-15 countries, Norway, and Switzerland; Timeline:  April 15, 2020

Study: Optimal Control applied to a SEIR model of 2019-nCoV with social distancing
Factors: social distancing i.e. reducing human contact in order to reduce the risk of infectivity
Excerpt: effective contact rate is unchanged (i.e. σ = 1), peak population infection rate of 9%; σ = 0.75 peak infection rate reduces to 6.3%; σ = 0.5 peak infection rate reduces to 2.6%

Study: A Stratified Model to Quantify the Effects of Containment Policies on the Spread of COVID-19
Factors: social distancing defined as interactions of people in [20-70] age range reduced to 20%, interactions of people 70+ reduced to 25%, and interactions of [0-20] age groups decreases to 20%
Excerpt: uncontained: eventual removed ratio 65.29%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 11.03%; R0 2.28; social distancing:  eventual removed ratio 9.46%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 3.72%; R0 0.49
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Iran Timeline: first 90 days COVID-19 spread

Study: A Stratified Model to Quantify the Effects of Containment Policies on the Spread of COVID-19
Factors: elderly social distancing: interactions of 70+ age groups decreases to 25%
Excerpt: uncontained: eventual removed ratio 65.29%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 11.03%; R0 2.28; elderly social distancing: eventual removed ratio 63.36%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 8.55%; R0 1.79
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Iran Timeline: first 90 days COVID-19 spread

Study: COVID-19 infection and recovery in various countries: Modeling the dynamics and evaluating the non-pharmaceutical mitigation scenarios
Factors: social distancing
Excerpt: No quarantine: 6.6% of the population never infected ; Social distancing: 27.3% of the population never infected

Study: The effect of control strategies to reduce social mixing on outcomes of the COVID-19 epidemic in Wuhan, China
Factors: physical distancing measures
Excerpt: N/A; 92% reduction in infections (IQR 66–97) and 24% (13–90) in mid-2020 and end-2020,
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; cities: Wuhan; Timeline: 1 year modeling period

Study: Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of public health measures to control COVID-19: a modelling study
Factors: community containment
Excerpt: N/A; The effective reproduction number (Re) was 1.84 (95%CI: 1.81, 1.87) and 3.80 (95%CI: 3.53, 4.06) respectively when the transmission constant was one in scenario I and II (Additional file 1: Table S4). Varying the transmission constant from the 0.25 to two, the isolation-and-quarantine was the most cost-effective single intervention, and program A was the most cost-effective joint intervention.

Study: The Effectiveness of Social Distancing in Mitigating COVID-19 Spread: a modelling analysis
Factors: community contact reduction i.e. social distancing measures aimed at preventing onward person-to-person virus transmission by minimizing contact
Excerpt: 66% infection rate (179,788 infected individuals) - no activation delay; 30% Community contact reduction (CCR) : 53.45% IR (145,592) 50% CCR: 41.45% IR (113,149) 70% CCR: 23.67% IR (64,492)
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Australia; cities: Newcastle; Timeline: 10 weeks

Study: Revealing the influence of national public health policies for the outbreak of the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic in Wuhan, China through status dynamic modeling
Factors: prohibiting public gathering events
Excerpt: There had already been 4,153 infected people and 6,536 exposed ones with the basic reproduction number of 2.65 before lockdown; , whereas  dropped to 1.98 for the first 30 days after the lockdown. The peak point is Feb. 17th, 2020 with 24,115 infected people and the end point is Jun. 17th, 2020. In t
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China cities: Wuhan; Timeline: Jan. 27th, 2020 - Feb. 2nd, 2020

Study: Effect of non-pharmaceutical interventions for containing the COVID-19 outbreak in China
Factors: inner-city contact reduction
Excerpt: 114,325 COVID-19 cases ( [IQR] 76,776 - 164,576); Without inner-city contact reduction, the number of COVID-19 cases would likely have shown a 2.6-fold increase (IQR: 1.7 - 3.7)

Study: Backcalculating the Incidence of Infection with COVID-19 on the Diamond Princess
Factors: movement restriction policy
Excerpt: Without intervention from 5 February onwards, it was predicted that the cumulative incidence with and without close contact would have been 1373 (95% CI: 570, 2176) and 766 (95% CI: 587, 946) cases, respectively; In the presence of intervention, the cumulative incidence among passengers with and without close contact and crew members were 102, 47 and 48 cases, respectively, as of 24 February 2020
